userreviews.userReview: One of my all-time favorites, this is an absolutely charming book that everyone should read.Julie Roseman is the divorced owner of a small flower shop in a Boston suburb; Romeo Cacciamani runs a competing flower shop on the other side of town. The two families have bitterly hated each other for decades, though no one can recall exactly how the feud started. When Romeo and Julie run into each other at a business seminar, they discover that not only do they not hate each other, they feel a mutual attraction. But they have to keep their affair secret because their grown children would be scandalized. Turning the traditional Romeo and Juliet on its head, Jeanne Ray's marvelous story zips along with the wit and elegance of a Shakespearean sonnet. Jeanne Ray's prose is absolutely sublime, and it's laced with humor.  One of the marvels of this story is that the main characters are not twenty-something twits. They're old enough to have grandkids, and prove the old adage that life does indeed begin at forty. The characters are realistic and you feel you could sit down and talk with them over coffee. I wish I could give this book more than five stars, because it's just so perfect.  It's probably true that literary talent runs in families, because Jeanne Ray is the mother of Ann Patchett, who has written several best sellers. I only wish Jeanne Ray had written more books.
For some reason I thought this was about a young guy and gal. Didn't matter though, I still liked it.

I read Jeanne Ray's Eat Cake recently, and like all good things, immediately wanted more of Ray's writing. Julie and Romeo is her first novel, published in 2000, and now I wish there were about a dozen more written between then and Eat Cake. Julie is the current owner of a florist shop. Romeo is the hated enemy owner of the rival flower shop. There the fun begins. Absent puffy sleeved velvet breeches, and weird feathered caps, I love this contemporary take on families feuding for generations and star-crossed lovers. That our protagonists are 60 makes it that much more delicious a story. Ray is a delightful writer, and her voice needs to be heard more. Please.
I loved Jeanne Ray's wise, witty and thoroughly modern take on Montagues and Capulets. This is a smart, funny, totally refreshing love story. Like the unexpected arrival of a bouquet of flowers.
I had a ball with these two families. It was a riot. I will have to look into this author more. She made me laugh out loud. It is so nice to read romance about older people.
A lovely entertaining read.

Absolutely wonderful romance novel of 60-year-olds in loveThe Cacciamanis and the Rosemans, who live in a small town near Boston, have been feuding for three generations, and Julie Roseman has no idea why. Yes, their families each run a florist's shop, but there is plenty of business for both stores. In the process of this feud, 15 years before, Julie's daughter Sandy fell in love with Tony Cacciamani when they were both 16. They were caught trying to elope and their families broke up their relationship. In addition to that, there have been countless vindictive, retaliatory acts on the part of both families over the years, and each side of the feud regards the other as criminal scum.When Julie married Mort Roth at age 20, her parents and Mort asked her to stop working in the flower shop since they could only afford one employee. Julie worked a few years as a secretary, then became a stay-at home wife and mother to her two daughters for thirty years--until the day when she and Mort were 55, and he dumped her to run off with a 38-year-old woman. At that point Julie's parents were dead, and since they had left the flower shop entirely to Julie, Mort could not demand a piece of it in the divorce.Julie has taken back her maiden name and has been running the shop the past five years, greatly enjoying the flowers, but struggling with the financial side of the business, both keeping the books and generating capital. At the start of this story, the economy is in a downturn, and Julie's business is barely surviving. In hopes of improving her chances of saving it, she attends a conference for small business owners and meets Romeo Cacciamani in person for the first time. She is amazed to find that she feels no animosity toward this handsome man with kind eyes, and he clearly holds no resentment personally toward her. She had heard from a distance that his wife had died a few years ago, and when she expresses her sympathy, Romeo asks her to have coffee with him. Thus quietly begins a relationship that is a source of wonder and emotional rebirth to the two of them, but is anything but to their respective families. When the Cacciamani and Roseman clans inevitably find out about Julie and Romeo's romance, all hell breaks lose, and everyone from Romeo's 90-year-old mother to Julie's 32-year-old realtor daughter do everything in their power to break up the star-crossed lovers.This exquisitely written Romeo-and-Juliet tale updated into a contemporary romance between two mature lovers is a joy to read. Though there is a lot of poignancy in the story, it is also filled with wry, ironic humor that is frequently laugh-out-loud funny. The author also creates love scenes between her two mature protagonists that are both sensual and incredibly tender. Best of all, the ending of the story is uplifting, triumphant and very, very entertaining.I loved this book when I read it for the first time many years ago, and it was just as terrific an experience for me the second time around.In short, everything about this book is flawless as far as I'm concerned, and this book is a true keeper.The Kindle edition I read is well edited and formatted.I rate this book as follows:Heroine: 5 starsHero: 5 starsSubcharacters: 5 starsRomance Plot: 5 starsWriting: 5 starsOverall: 5 stars

"What's in a name ? That which we call a rose by any other word would still be as sweet" ~~~~~William Shakespeare , Romeo and Juliet. This story is another take on Shakespeare's play,it is not however a bunch of teenagers in "Westside Story " no Julie and Romeo are in their 60s and both have Grandchildren ,Julie is Jewish and has been divorced for many years,Romeo is Italian and his Wife has died a few years ago.their families have been rival florists and hated each other for three generations but they can't remember why. Julie and Romeo bump into each other at a small business seminar,share a cup of coffee at Starbucks ( where else? ) and one thing leads to another,they fall in love ( yes,I know it's shocking that people of that age would do such a thing ?) and their Children start up the age old feud again, but nothing can stop their love. This is a story for Children of all age's.

I thought this was a fun story that reminds us that our parents are just older versions of ourselves. Someday we will be that age and want to be treated with respect and not be regarded as complete loons when we do something out of the ordinary that everyone is used to. I also loved that the main character looked at a long-standing family feud and worked to stop the cycle of anger. I have never been in such a powerfully angry situation but I can not imagine the toll it takes on you to be sooo angry with someone. Lucky me! May I stay so oblivious for a long time! warning: had some language and 60 yr old spiciness
Easy romantic read for February

Ok, I get it, I get it......Life is not over at 60 and mature adults live passionate and fulfilling lives and are capable of all the head swooning emotion of pubescent teenagers...yadda, yadda, yadda. I heard ya the first 10 times already!!! I'm glad this was not my first sojourn into the world of Jeanne Ray. She seemed so desperate to re-sex the previous generation that there wasn't room for much more.....and yet I still found myself reading. Because I do like the characters of her world and I am anxious to see how things play out for them---despite my frustration with Julie and Romeo's willingness to let their families walk all over them. I mean are you 60 or not???? Doesn't that earn you the right to be an adult and tell your family to deal or get lost??? Her life after 40 point was so over-driven in this book that had I read it first I probably wouldn't have read any of her other books. By Step Ball Change and Eat Cake she honed her exuberance for the sectarian set and made a much for subtle and enjoyable point. DISCLAIMER--I will be reading the sequel to this book, Julie and Romeo Get Lucky, despite my misgivings about the original. As said before I do like this cast of characters and I am anxious to see them all grow up and move on---even those who are 60 or older. I also felt that the ending was bit too simplistic of a wrap up for decades of hatred so I will be interested in seeing if things in the post-feud world are really all rosy. And I would love to see Julie and Romeo weather real life together and be happy despite the monotony of it all. And that strikes at the essence of Ray's books, the belief in marriage and love despite extreme disappointments and set backs. And that's exactly what I want to believe in my life too and so I read them!

You want to know the one thing I really wanted to belated advise author Jeanne Ray about? Oh, of course you do.That is: do not put, on your author statement, that you are Ann Patchett's mom. Really. I don't care what your editors and publisher told you, don't do it. Don't go there. Don't invite me to compare your work to that of your daughter (one of my favorite contemporary novelists). And don't set me up for wondering--yeah, I know, it's fiction, of course you aren't talking about Real Life and your Family and your best friend, even though the best friend in the novel and your best friend are admittedly sharing a name--don't set me up for wondering "hmmm, now is Ann the bitchy daughter or the sloppy one?"But hey, it's a nice read. It is unthreatening and sweet. There are grandchildren. There are adult daughters. There is an ex husband (how did your Julie ever hook up with that guy?). There are flowers. There are people who, while they apparently run small businesses (into the ground), don't really have to keep business hours or worry their heads about stuff except as it fits the plot.All of that is typical fun chic lit.And to have a main character who is a passionate 60 year old woman? Very cool, though I was sort of uncomfortably imagining the reactions of the 20 something readers to the sex scenes. I mean, are they going to react the way I did when my older, 10 year old, bff explained the sex act to me ("NOOOO, our parents would Never Do That!!!")?And lots of weddings and sort of weddings? Well,isn't that fun?It's a respectably written fun book, and I will probably look for others by Ray. But..gosh, don't bring your daughter into it, okay?

I was surprised to find that this book is actually about two people in their sixties - the blurb makes it sound like the typical romance where two twenty-somethings fall in love. I ended up loving the new dynamics that were introduced because of the characters' ages, like the fact that they both have children. The obstacles that Julie and Romeo face in their relationship felt interesting and new because there are so few books that tell stories like this. As with most any modern retelling of Romeo and Juliet, the family rivalry requires some suspension of disbelief. Still, I thought the adaptation was nice because (spoiler alert!) it does not end with a tragic death. Overall, a sweet and lighthearted book that I'm sure would resonate even more with an older audience. Think Love in the Time of Cholera but without the murder/suicide/rape. Also, Romeo and Julie both own flower shops - too cute.(P.S. First book of 2016! Yay!)

I'll begin my review by stating the negative. It was so annoying to read about Julie and Romeo (especially Julie) not being able to stand up for themselves against their families. I mean, they are 60 years old! Act like it by not letting their children push them around and boss them around. If my children tried to order me around, I would have put them in their places right then and there. With the negative out of the way, Julie and Romeo was a very delightful read. I have about twenty years before I get to my sixties, and this book gives me hope that maybe I will have love and sex even when I get up there in years. Who knows? But, anyway, the book was entertaining and amusing. Their budding romance was very sweet to read about. I've already marked "to read" the second book of the series. Looking forward to reading that one.

This modern day Romeo and Juliet type story has plenty of twists from Shakespeare's. The biggest difference is this isn't love lost teenagers....both of the main characters have been married previously, have grown children, and are about 60 years old. They still come from feuding families and there has been plenty of hate and disgust over the years. I laughed out loud and some of the situations these characters get into! This is a modern day book with no thought of saving "it" for marriage and there is a BIG swear word used by one of the hateful children when they find out about the parent's love for the enemy. I was grateful the language was a one time thing. I enjoyed the characters and their real life complexities so much, it would have been hard to quit reading it. A quick, summer romance read.

As you can gather by the name, Julie and Romeo have families that don't like each other, to say the least. Throughout the entire book, up until the end, you don't know exactly why the relationships between the Rosemans and Cacciamanis have always been in contention. And the funny part is - neither do they! Only one surviving family member knows the reason...and the do not let go of the secret very easily!One of my favorite aspects of this book is the background of flowers via the two florist shops. Jeanne Ray obviously did some research on this subject because her descriptions of the flowers and arrangements make the flowers pop out in your mind. The flowers are only second to the love that blooms in this beautiful garden of a book.

The person sitting next to me on a plane stuck on the tarmac in Chicago due to a very exciting storm, gave this book to me when she had finished it. Both our noses were glued to our books during the long flight west to Seattle. Can't even remember what I was reading (must've been really good) and since I only started it on the flight, didn't finish it. Otherwise I would've made an exchange (maybe I offered anyway - can't remember). So, about the book - it's a nice, light, romantic story about a star-crossed elderly couple. Lots of humor and likable characters. It's a different kind of Romeo & Juliet - a modern version.

Julie and Romeo is a very entertaining spin on the story of Romeo and Juliet. I like what the author says about what inspired her to write it: "While my husband and I were watching the video of Romeo and Juliet, the question of what might have happened had the grandparents of these two youngsters fallen in love occured to me." The perspective completely caught me by surprise! It's a fun, quick read, although there is a lot of sexual content. Still, this is a fun and completely unique love story.

I first read Julie and Romeo in 2005 and really liked it, this time in 2014 I LOVE it! I'd forgotten how laugh out-loud funny it is. The interactions between the family members remind me of just how wonderful and impossible families are, often all at the same time. Jeanne Ray knows family and has a real talent for capturing the reality of I-love-you-but-I'd-like-to-strangle-you-right-now of relationships. Written with such skill that the humor (or tenderness) of the tale is never over-done. This one is a keeper! 4.5 stars.

So glad I discovered Jeanne Ray--what a marvelously funny writer! This book is a takeoff on Romeo and Juliet, but instead of a tragedy, it's a romantic comedy. The Rosemans and the Cacciamanis, owners of rival florist shops, are combatants who don't even remember why they hate each other. All is well until the divorced Julie Roseman and the widowed Romeo Cacciamani meet by chance and are instantly attracted. Julie and Romeo are both 60, one of the other things I really liked about this story, and it's their children (and her ex-husband) who conspire to keep them apart.

Light, fun little romance for us of the older set. I enjoyed it and understood the heroine's concern about what her children thought - to a point. After a while, it got extremely annoying that she wouldn't just stand up for herself and, at 60, let them know that she was going to live her life as she saw fit. The "secret" at the end was rather weak, too, I thought. All in all, a fun summer read, though.

This book re-tells the tale of Romeo and Juliet from a modern perspective. It's about an older couple who falls in love, and their feuding families.It's a light read, but thoroughly engrossing and enjoyable. I enjoyed it so much that I read it twice! (You can read the entire book in a couple hours.)Since then, I've sought out other books by Jeanne Ray. She has a wonderful writing style and the ability to tell a story that pulls you in. You'll love all the characters!

This book was enjoyable -- it is a lighthearted retelling of the Romeo and Juliet story, but this time the protagnists are in their sixties and their families, who own the competing town florist shops, have been fueding for years. It has good characterization and humor and moves along quickly; however, it does have some adult situations and language that I felt were not necessary.

I read this at a friend's house and it's a delightful book. First, I loved it because it isn't often someone writes a romance for my age group. And the history (mostly bad) between these two families makes the romance between the star-crossed lovers hilarious. Fortunately, it turns out better than Shakespeare's version! This is a good, fun read.

Enjoyed it - easy read - charming. Some comical moments and liked the "over-fifty" romance! Gee, older people can still find love?? What a nice thought! I enjoy this writer, even though her books are light and what some call "fluffy." They make me smile. Probably would make a light and comical movie that a "goodreads" friend mentioned.

A wonderful story of love finding a slightly older couple@! Julie and Romeo's families, both in the flower business, have a longstanding feud, the origins of which everyone's forgotten. Their grown children are aghast when they fall in love--will true love prevail? The sequel, Julie and Romeo get Lucky, is also wonderful. All of Jeanne Ray's books are a treat--especially Eat Cake.

Easy to read romance. Read it in one evening. A little over the top in some areas but it was needed for the story line, I guess. I did like that the love story was between 60 year olds. I think a lot of the "romantic line" publishing forgets that older people need romance too.
What a sweet book! Romance with older couple. Love at any age. Enjoyable.
My favorite author! Jeanne Ray proves you can have a brand new unexpected career later in life. All of her women are amazing strong characters.
Light funny read. I liked it a lot. About two florists who grew up hating each other and don’t know why. They’re in their 60s. He’s a widower, she’s divorced and the kids get in the mix.

description: A deliciously funny and wickedly sexy novel of love found (finally!) and love threatened (inevitably) by the families who claim to love us best. Romeo Cacciamani and Julie Roseman are rival florists in Boston, whose families have hated each other for as long as anyone can remember (what they can't remember is why). When these two vital, lonely people see each other across a crowded lobby at a small business owners' seminar, an intense attraction blooms that neither tries to squelch. They're not sure what fate has in store for them, but they're not about to let something as silly as a generations-long feud stand in the way of finding out. That is, not until Romeo's octogenarian mother, Julie's meddling ex-husband, and a cast of grown Cacciamani and Roseman children begin to intervene with a passionate hatred that matches their newly found love, stroke for stroke. Think Montagues and Capulets, think wise and witty and thoroughly modern. Julie and Romeo is a love story for the ages. All ages.
title:
Julie and Romeo
      
          (Julie and Romeo #1)
